Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: MINERVA - A dedicated, global, precision radial velocity machine for TESS
Award.AbstractNarration: A research collaboration between Harvard University, George Mason University, the University of California-Riverside, and the University of Montana will use a telescope network to observe planet candidates orbiting nearby stars. The planet candidates have been identified by NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS). Planets will be confirmed, their masses and orbits will be measured. The work will help create improved theories of the formation and evolution of planets with a broad range of environments. Some of the planets confirmed will be the ones that provide the best chance of detecting life in the future. The award will fund students to participate in Harvard's Banneker Institute. This undergraduate summer program focuses on recruiting under-represented minorities for a program of research, graduate school preparation, and social justice education.<br/><br/>The investigation will employ two dedicated robotic arrays of four 0.7-meter telescopes (MINERVA-North and MINERVA-Australis) in both hemispheres for all sky access to confirm and characterize TESS planet candidates. The facilities will perform a large scale survey to measure the orbital obliquities of approximately 180 planets, enabling a more robust understanding of formation and migration of planets as a function of the properties of the host star and their planets. MINERVA will also measure planet masses and orbital eccentricities, and search for additional planets in each system. The confirmation and characterization of new planetary systems around the bright TESS host stars will identify the best possible targets for future detailed follow up. The planets confirmed and characterized will be the ones the next generation of space-borne exoplanet missions and ground-based extremely large telescopes will prioritize to measure the detailed atmospheric compositions and will provide the best chances of detecting biomarkers. The survey will allow a more detailed understanding of planet formation and migration as a function of stellar and planetary properties. The nature of exoplanet observations generates opportunities for projects ideal for student involvement at all levels. In addition, MINERVA's dedicated array of small telescopes provides a unique platform to develop valuable instrumentation experience. MINERVA provides a scientific backbone for undergraduate research opportunities, undergraduate theses, post-baccalaureate research experience, and graduate research experience.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With respect to exoplanets, we live in an age of magnificent
discovery. These discoveries are still relatively recent, with the
vast majority occurring over the past few decades. As such, we are
still grappling with many of the new findings, some of which challenge
planetary models that are derived purely from Solar System
observations. While the Solar System remains our best studied example
of a planetary system, observations of exoplanets have expanded our
horizons to reveal planets and planetary system architectures that are
substantially different from our home system. Some of these new
planetary types include hot Jupiters, sub-Neptunes, and volatile-rich
terrestrial planets. These include systems, some orbiting G dwarfs
like our Sun, where multiple planets are found within the equivalent
of the orbit of Mercury.

Fundamental planetary properties include the mass of the planet and
the shape of the orbit. These properties may be extracted by measuring
the radiel velocity (RV) of the star, influenced by the gravitational
effects of the orbiting planet. A major activity of this project
involved the assessment of exoplanet targets from the Transiting
Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) and their suitability for RV
follow-up observations. Current RV programs for ephemeris refinement
rely on semi-consistent monitoring of targets. However, facilities
that can produce such observations are limited, necessitating
optimization of observations. Graduate student, Zhexing Li, has
conducted thousands of simulations that test the orbital period
uncertainty reduction against three variables: number, epoch, and
orbital phase coverage of synthetic future observations. The attached
figure shows one of the simulation results that varies the number of
future observations for the known exoplanet host, HD 134987. The
orbital period uncertainty shows an initial drastic decline, whereby
additional data points do not significantly improve the orbital
ephemeris. The results of this work has produced a relationship
describing the ephemeris improvement with respect to these three
variables, allowing this project to extend orbital refinement work to
all targets and plan the most efficient precursor
observations. Furthermore, Zhexing has made numerous improvements to
the radial velocity code, particularly modoficiations that better
account for highly eccentric orbits and large mass ratios of companion
to host star. Zhexing has also expanded RadVel to incorporate orbital
dynamics in multi-planet systems. These results are currently being
prepared for publication.

The second outcome of this project is the discovery of TOI-1994b, a
low-mass brown dwarf transiting a hot subgiant star on a moderately
eccentric orbit. This work was led by graduate student Emma Page, and
included the analysis of MINERVA RV data in combination with other
sources of RV data, as well as photoetry from TESS. Shown in the
attached image is the combined RV data for this star, along with the
best-fit model, that clearly shows the gravitational influence of the
brown dwarf. The brown dwarf has a mass of around 22 times the mass of
Jupiter and orbits its host star once every 4.034 days. With precise
age, mass, and radius, the global analysis and characterization of
TOI-1994b augments the small number of transiting brown dwarfs and
allows the testing of substellar evolution models. This result has
been submitted for publication in the American Astronomical Society
journals.
